remarks: The reverse of ~ dvfsumrlim , when comparing a finite sum of _increasing_ terms to an integral.  In this case there is no point in stating the limit properties, because the terms of the sum aren't approaching zero, but there is nevertheless still a natural asymptotic statement that can be made.  (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 20-May-2016.)
statement:
dvfsum2.s $e |- S = ( T (,) +oo ) $.
dvfsum2.z $e |- Z = ( ZZ>= ` M ) $.
dvfsum2.m $e |- ( ph -> M e. ZZ ) $.
dvfsum2.d $e |- ( ph -> D e. RR ) $.
dvfsum2.u $e |- ( ph -> U e. RR* ) $.
dvfsum2.md $e |- ( ph -> M <_ ( D + 1 ) ) $.
dvfsum2.t $e |- ( ph -> T e. RR ) $.

dvfsum2.b2 $e |- ( ( ph /\ x e. Z ) -> B e. RR ) $.
dvfsum2.b3 $e |- ( ph -> ( RR _D ( x e. S |-> A ) ) = ( x e. S |-> B ) ) $.
dvfsum2.c $e |- ( x = k -> B = C ) $.
dvfsum2.l $e |- ( ( ph /\ ( x e. S /\ k e. S ) /\ ( D <_ x /\ x <_ k /\ k <_ U ) ) -> B <_ C ) $.
dvfsum2.g $e |- G = ( x e. S |-> ( sum_ k e. ( M ... ( |_ ` x ) ) C - A ) ) $.
dvfsum2.0 $e |- ( ( ph /\ ( x e. S /\ D <_ x ) ) -> 0 <_ B ) $.
dvfsum2.1 $e |- ( ph -> X e. S ) $.
dvfsum2.2 $e |- ( ph -> Y e. S ) $.
dvfsum2.3 $e |- ( ph -> D <_ X ) $.
dvfsum2.4 $e |- ( ph -> X <_ Y ) $.
dvfsum2.5 $e |- ( ph -> Y <_ U ) $.
dvfsum2.e $e |- ( x = Y -> B = E ) $.
dvfsum2 $p |- ( ph -> ( abs ` ( ( G ` Y ) - ( G ` X ) ) ) <_ E ) $.
